dispassion.title: Paṭhama aparijānana sutta - Not Completely Comprehending (First)

dispassion.title: Paṭhama dārukkhandhopama sutta - Simile of the Wooden Log (First)

dispassion.title: Pariñña sutta - Full Understanding
dispassion.description: The Buddha teaches the things to be fully understood and what full understanding is.

dispassion.title: Dutiya kassapa sutta - Kassapa (Second)

dispassion.title: Sakkāra sutta - Respect
dispassion.description: The Blessed One describes how beings are affected by respect and disrespect, and how this affects their rebirth. The true person is one who is collected, detached, and delights in the ending of grasping.

dispassion.title: Diṭṭhigata sutta - Two Kinds Of Wrong Views

equanimity.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
equanimity.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

equanimity.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka

ethical conduct.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

ethical conduct.title: Attarakkhita sutta - Self-Protection
ethical conduct.description: Even if protected by an entire army, one who engages in misconduct is unprotected. But one who engages in good conduct protects themselves, even without external protection.

ethical conduct.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
ethical conduct.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

ethical conduct.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth

ethical conduct.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. ethical conduct.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna

ethical conduct.title: Sukhapatthanā sutta - Aspiring for Happiness

ethical conduct.title: Putta sutta - Child

ethical conduct.title: Moneyya sutta - Sagacity

flexible.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind

full awareness.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy

one-pointedness.title: Paṁsudhovaka sutta - The Dirt Rinser

patience.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha
patience.description: DhammaPada verses 179-196 describe the boundless and traceless nature of the Buddha, the teachings of all the Buddhas, rarity of a human birth, rarity of the arising of a Buddha, what is a safe refuge that leads to release from suffering, and the merit gained by ones who honor the Buddhas or their disciples.

recognition of impermanence.title: Avijjāpahāna sutta - Abandoning Ignorance
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha teaches on how to know and see the impermanence of the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception for the abandoning of ignorance and the arising of wisdom.

recognition of impermanence.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

recognition of impermanence.title: Bhidura sutta - Fragile
recognition of impermanence.description: The body is fragile, consciousness is of a fading nature. All substrates of existence are impermanent, dissatisfactory, and subject to change.

recognition of impermanence.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
recognition of impermanence.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. recognition of not-self.title: Ānanda sutta - With Ānanda
recognition of not-self.description: When the venerable Ānanda wishes to go for a solitary retreat, the Buddha teaches him to contemplate the five aggregates subject to appropriation and being assumed as one's self.

recollection of death.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
recollection of death.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

respect.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
respect.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

respect.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī

respect.title: Sakkāra sutta - Respect
respect.description: The Blessed One describes how beings are affected by respect and disrespect, and how this affects their rebirth. The true person is one who is collected, detached, and delights in the ending of grasping.

respect.title: Sabrahmaka sutta - With Brahmā
respect.description: Where children honor their mother and father, those families are said to dwell with Brahmā.

wholesome.title: Chappāṇakopama sutta - The Simile of the Six Animals
wholesome.description: The Buddha explains how there is non-restraint and restraint with a simile of six animals with different domains and feeding grounds. He uses strong post or pillar as a designation for mindfulness directed to the body.

wholesome.title: Putta sutta - Child
wholesome.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

wholesome.title: Dutiya dāna sutta - Giving (Second)
wholesome.description: Wholesome giving along with faith and a sense of right and wrong is the way of practice that leads to the world of gods.

wholesome.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
wholesome.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

wholesome.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
wholesome.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

wholesome.title: Adhamma vagga - The Chapter On Not The Teaching
wholesome.description: The Buddha shares the importance of explaining correctly what is not the Dhamma, discipline, spoken or uttered, practiced, and prescribed by the Tathāgata.

wisdom.title: Upāsaka sutta - Lay Disciple
wisdom.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance contrasting one who has comprehended the nature of reality with one who is with possessions.

wisdom.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
wisdom.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
wisdom.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

wisdom.title: Avijjāpahāna sutta - Abandoning Ignorance
wisdom.description: The Buddha teaches on how to know and see the impermanence of the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception for the abandoning of ignorance and the arising of wisdom.

wisdom.title: Bāḷisikopama sutta - The Fisherman's Simile
wisdom.description: The Buddha likens the six types of desirable sense objects to baited hooks, set in the world for the misfortune of beings—those who cling to them fall under Māra’s power.

wisdom.title: Paṭhama samudda sutta - Ocean (First)
wisdom.description: The Buddha uses the simile of an ocean to describe the six sense bases and their respective objects.

wisdom.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
wisdom.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

wisdom.title: Sakkapañha sutta - Sakka's Question
wisdom.description: The Buddha answers Sakka's question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very life.

wisdom.title: Rādha sutta - Rādha
wisdom.description: The Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha on how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies to self-identification, possessiveness, and pride cease to arise.

wisdom.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
wisdom.description: After examining the impermanence, dis-satisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, with identifying with them.

wisdom.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
wisdom.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

wisdom.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
wisdom.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī

wisdom.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

wisdom.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma

wisdom.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

wisdom.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
wisdom.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

wisdom.title: Dhātusosaṁsandana sutta - The Coming Together of Elements
wisdom.description: Beings come together and associate with other beings according to their disposition. Therefore, one should avoid associating with those that are lazy and keep company with the wise.

wisdom.title: Sikkhānisaṁsa sutta - With Training as Benefit
wisdom.description: The Buddha advises to live with training as the benefit, wisdom as the north star, liberation as the essence, ruled by mindfulness.

wisdom.title: Paññāparihīna sutta - Lacking in Wisdom
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the sentient beings who lack in wisdom as truly deprived, dwelling in suffering, annoyance, hardship, and distress.

wisdom.title: Ugga sutta - Ugga

wisdom.title: Vitthatadhana sutta - Wealth in Detail
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in detail, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom. One who possesses these is not truly poor, and their life is not lived in vain.

wisdom.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in brief, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Vibhatti sutta - Analytical Knowledges
wisdom.description: Venerable Sāriputta describes the four analytical knowledges he realized a half-month after his full ordination.

wisdom.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

wisdom.title: Paṭicchanna sutta - Obscured
wisdom.description: Three things thrive when obscured, not when exposed. And three things that shine forth when exposed, not when obscured.

wisdom.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

wisdom.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
wisdom.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

wisdom.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
wisdom.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

wisdom.title: Aṭṭhāna vagga - The Chapter On The Impossible
wisdom.description: Short teachings on the impossibility of certain events, actions, or outcomes.

wise attention.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy

suffering.title: Bhaddaka sutta - Auspicious

suffering.title: Akammaniya vagga - The Chapter On The Ineffective
suffering.description: The Buddha contrasts the undeveloped and developed mind.

suffering.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
